entry.et: Middle English rokken, from Old English roccian; akin to Old High German rucken to cause to move

def.dt: :to move back and forth in or as if in a cradle
:to cause to sway back and forth a boat rocked by the waves
:to cause to shake violently
:to daze with or as if with a vigorous blow a hard right rocked the contender
:to astonish or disturb greatly the scandal rocked the community
:to rouse to excitement (as by performing rock music) rocked the crowd
:to become moved backward and forward under often violent impact
:to move gently back and forth
:to move forward at a steady pace
:to move forward at a high speed the train rocked through the countryside
:to sing, dance to, or play rock music
:to be extremely enjoyable, pleasing, or effective her new car rocks
:to do something that disturbs the equilibrium of a situation
:a rocking movement

:popular music usually played on electronically amplified instruments and characterized by a persistent heavily accented beat, repetition of simple phrases, and often country, folk, and blues elements

entry.et: Middle English roc, from Middle Dutch rocke; akin to Old High German rocko distaff

def.dt: :distaff
:the wool or flax on a distaff

entry.et: Middle English rokke, from Old French dialect (Norman & Picard) roke, from Vulgar Latin *rocca

def.dt: :a large mass of stone forming a cliff, promontory, or peak
:a concreted mass of stony material
:broken pieces of such masses
:consolidated or unconsolidated solid mineral matter
:a particular mass of it
:something like a rock in firmness:
:foundation support
:refuge a rock of independent thought … in an ocean of parochialism Thomas Molnar
:something that threatens or causes disaster often used in plural
:a flavored stick candy with color running through
:rock candy 1
:gem
:diamond
:a small crystallized mass of crack cocaine
:crack 9
:the ball used in basketball

dro.drp: between a rock and a hard place

vr.va: between the rock and the hard place

def.dt: :in a difficult or uncomfortable position with no attractive way out
:in or into a state of destruction or wreckage their marriage is on the rocks
:on ice cubes bourbon on the rocks
river 300 miles (483 kilometers) S Wisconsin & N Illinois flowing S & SW into the Mississippi at Rock Island
:rock 2
:rocker 3
:a brown spotted sunfish (Ambloplites rupestris) found especially in the upper Mississippi River valley and Great Lakes region
:the lowest or most fundamental part or level
:being the very lowest rock–bottom prices
:fundamental the rock–bottom question
